Dialogue: Here comes the next pitch. Even tighter. Jack nearly hit.

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Ball two! Jack glaring, crowds the plate more. Bragan shows 1, taps his right thigh signalling outside. Jack watches it sail, doesn't bite. The umpire: Ball Three! Higbe's fun slipping away as he can't find the strike zone.

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: Come on, Rook! Ain't you gonna swing at something?! Jack takes a practice swing, waits as Bragan sets up right over the plate. Here comes the pitch. Low. Ball four!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: It's just a walk.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Who can blame them?

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: Looks ill-tempered over to first where Jack gives the same look back as he sidesteps an enormous, defiant lead off the bag. Higbe incredulous. Did he just do that?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Watching from a seat behind third.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Thataway, Jackie! Thataway!

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: Hell! You're supposed to go back to third when I step off! Don't you know nothing?! He throws over. Jack back to the bag. Higbe gets the ball back, looks in. Jack bouncing, pounding off third. His movements carry violence within them. Like a piston exploding in an engine. Higbe into his motion, stops his delivery, accidentally drops the ball to the ground. The umpire signals BALK, points Jack home. Higbe is furious.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I don't understand. What happened?

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: It's a balk, Mama. The pitcher can't start toward home and then stop. Jackie scores.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: But he didn't do anything.

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: Oh, mama, yes he did, he discombobulated the man.

Speaker: dugout
Dialogue: Durocher looks to Branca, impressed.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: He didn't come to play; he came to kill. Durocher starts out to the mound to talk to Higbe.

Speaker: dixie walker
Dialogue: Watching from right field, the black crowd still cheering. He walks over toward the open bullpen where Casey stands.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: This really how it's gonna be some day? Baseball?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Git offa this field now!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What!? Why?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: It's against the law is why. No niggers don't play with no white boys. Git off or go to jail. Jack shrugs the policeman's hand off his shoulder. That sends him reaching for his nightstick and -- Sukeforth is there to get between them.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You swing that thing you better hit me between the eyes with it.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Is that so? The CROWD BOOING. The black section especially.

Speaker: hopper
Dialogue: Hey, hold on, what'd he do wrong?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: We ain't havin' Nigras mix with white boys in this town. Ya'll ain't up-states now; they gotta stay separate. Brooklyn Dodgers ain't changing our way of living. Where are you all from anyhow?

Speaker: hopper
Dialogue: Greenwood, Mississippi.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Hell, man, you oughta know better.  Now tell your Nigra I said to git. You think I'm foolin'? Hopper looks desperately to Jack who just stands there.

Speaker: rachel's voice
Dialogue: What did you do?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I said okay, Skipper, tell him... Ah'm a-gittin'. Sho'nuff, ah is.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You didn't?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I did. Then I took a long shower. We lost 2 to 1. She takes a few exaggerated steps to amuse him.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Ah'm a-gittin', ah'm a gittin'. He laughs, takes her hand. He's going to kiss her.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You're not getting away from me.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Get back, Rae. Go back. Cracker stops square across from him. Jack's fists balled.

Speaker: cracker
Dialogue: I want you to know something.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yeah, what's that?

Speaker: cracker
Dialogue: I want you to know I'm pulling for you to make good. And a lot of folks here feel the same way. If a man's got the goods, he deserves a fair chance. That's all.  Ma'am. As Cracker walks away... Rachel takes Jack's hand.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You wanted to see me, Mr. Rickey? Rickey nods, consider the field a moment.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Bermuda grass grows so well here. I wish we could get it to grow like this in Brooklyn.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I like the way it smells when they mow it.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Me, too. Rickey consider the field a moment, then Jack.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Jackie, it's my pleasure to tell you that you've earned a spot on the Montreal Royals. When they head north Tuesday for opening day against Jersey City, you'll be on the train. Jack trying to hold down his excitement.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I won't let you down.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I know that.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If you don't mind, I've got to go tell my wife.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Give her my regards. Jack about to head off when he looks back..

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I'm an opportunist. With you and the Negro players I hope to bring up next year I'll put together a team that can win the World Series. And the World Series means money. Jack studies him a beat, not quite buying it.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Don't you believe that?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I don't think what I believe is important. Only what I do.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Agreed. Therefore, run the bases like the Devil himself.

Speaker: train tracks
Dialogue: The train picks up speed. The boys start to run. Arms pumping, feet flying. One boy drops off. Then the other. But Ed still runs. Chasing after that train carrying Jackie Robinson. Finally, he stops, heaving for breath, watching the train disappear around the bend. A lonely beat. Then -- Ed gets down on his hands and knees. He sets his ear on the rail, closes his eyes. A thrum comes off the rail. A huge smile spreads. He straightens, shouts back to his friends:

Speaker: crowd voice
Dialogue: Come on, Jackie, this fella can't pitch! Speaking of the pitch, here it comes. Jack tops a WEAK GROUNDER to short. As he's thrown out by a mile...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I think I might be sick.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'd be sick at a swing like that, too.

Speaker: older woman
Dialogue: Are you alright, honey?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm sick. I don't know why. The older woman rolls off a piece of paper towel for her.

Speaker: older woman
Dialogue: When did you have your monthly last?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm late.

Speaker: older woman
Dialogue: It may be that you're pregnant. The older woman offers a little smile, leaves her there. INSERT: Third Inning.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Come on, Jackie. Come on, batter.

Speaker: hopper
Dialogue: I'll be damned...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Oh, Jack... Oh Jack...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Jack! Jack! INSERT: November 18, 1946. Pasadena, California. She is in labor and we are in Huntington Memorial Hospital. A CRY. The DOCTOR holds up a slick, wailing NEWBORN.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It's a boy. As Rachel holds out her arms for him...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: My daddy left. He left us flat in Cairo, Georgia. I was only six months older than you are now. I don't remember him. Nothing good, nothing bad. Nothing.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: As all of us know a young Negro second baseman played north of the border last season... INSERT: Brooklyn YMCA. February 5, 1947. In back: TWO DEACONS in the back whisper over a SPORTS PAGE.

Speaker: deacon one
Dialogue: Look here what he did.

Speaker: deacon two
Dialogue: Last season doesn't matter. The International League, it doesn't matter. What matters is this year. What matters is Brooklyn.

Speaker: deacon one
Dialogue: Shhh... Here he comes. As Herbert Miller introduces...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I present the general manager of the Brooklyn Dodger baseball club, Mr. Branch Rickey! Warm APPLAUSE as Rickey steps up. As it settles...

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Good evening. I have something very important to talk with you about tonight. Something that will require courage from all of us.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: He may stay there or he may be brought to Brooklyn. But if Jackie does come up to the Dodgers, the biggest threat to his success, the one enemy most likely to ruin that success, is the Negro people themselves! There is shocked silence in the room. Rickey notices a group of KIDS watching from a raised running track, soldiers on:

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I say it as cruelly as I can to make you all realize the weight of responsibility that is not only on myself and the Dodgers, but on Negroes everywhere. For on the day Jackie enters the National League, if he does, I have no doubt every one of you will form parades and welcoming committees. You'll strut. You'll wear badges. You'll hold Jackie Robinson days and Jackie Robinson nights. You'll get drunk, fight and be arrested. This is too much. People are slackjawed. Rickey powers on.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You'll wine and dine him until he is fat and futile. You'll symbolize his importance into a national comedy and yes, a tragedy! So let me tell you this!  If any group or segment of Negro society uses the advancement of Jackie Robinson in baseball as a triumph of race over race, I will regret the day I ever signed him to a contract, and I will personally see that baseball is never so abused and misrepresented again! Is he done? An embarrassed smattering of applause. Mostly shock and stares. As Rickey stands there uncomfortably...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: I question your bedside manner, Mr. Rickey, but they've agreed to set up a committee of self-policing. We'll call it the 'Don't Spoil Jackie's Chances' campaign.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Miller. I'm sorry; the spotlight will be on us all.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: rickey's voice
Dialogue: Hello, Leo, what are you doing?

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I'm bowling. Wait, I'm snowshoeing in the Alps. I'm trying to sleep, Mr. Rickey. It's still dark out.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Another spring training is upon us. In Panama. I need to know your attitude toward Jackie Robinson.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I don't got an attitude toward him. The girl rolls over to look at him. She is the actress LORRAINE DAY and she is stunning. As Durocher regards her...

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Eight times in the Bible we're told to love our neighbor. It's one of God's most repeated commands.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I don't know much about the Bible.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: If by nice you mean soft, no, not particularly.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Good. He can't afford to be. Nice guys finish last.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: So you have no objections to him?

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: None whatsoever. Can I go back to sleep now?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Yes. Oh -- and Leo?

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: The Bible says a thing or two about adultery as well.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I'm sure it's got a lot to say about a lot. Good night. Durocher hangs up the phone, looks to her.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Promise me you'll write.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: When did I ever not write?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I want you to know I'm there for you. Even if it's words on paper. He's sees she's raw, takes her in his arms with the baby.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Rae, you're in my heart. She sighs, rests her head on his shoulder.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You're getting close now. The closer you get, the worse they'll be. Don't let them get to you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I will not. God built me to last. He kisses her. She kisses him back.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: See you in Brooklyn in eight weeks.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It might be Montreal. A certainty grips her. She passes it on to him.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's going to be Brooklyn. I know it is. Power in her words. He nods, looks off toward the taxi.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: It's a pipe dream, Mr. Rickey.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Pipe dream? What do you mean by pipe dream?

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I mean it ain't gonna happen. The Dodgers are never gonna demand Robinson be brought up from Montreal. Ball players are conservative.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: A team full of tough war veterans? Immigrants' sons? Boys from impoverished parts of the country?

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: It - ain't - gonna - happen.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You really believe they won't accept him? Once they see how he plays, how he can help them win.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I'm not saying they won't accept him: I'm saying they won't ask for him. I'm saying Robinson's good medicine, but they're not gonna like the taste. I'm saying bend over, boys, and get ready, this one might hurt a little.

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: Why do you think Rickey's got us playing spring games in Panama?

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: We, the undersigned Brooklyn Dodgers will not play ball on the same field as Jackie Robinson. Higbe signs it. He hands the pen to Bragan who adds his own name. Casey signs with a flourish. Casey holds out the pen to Walker who doesn't take it right away. An odd beat.

Speaker: casey
Dialogue: If you wanna make your mark, Dixie, we can witness it. Everyone laughs; it loosens Walker up enough to sign.

Speaker: stanky's voice
Dialogue: C'mon in!

Speaker: stanky's room
Dialogue: The boys enter. Eddie Stanky sits in a chair stripped to the waist, soaking his right elbow in a BUCKET OF ICE.

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: What's goin' on?

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: Got a petition goin' on, Stank.

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: Oh... Did Pee Wee sign it?

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: Ain't asked him yet. What difference does it make?

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: None, just wonderin'.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Look, it's like this. I got a wife, a baby, and I got no money. I don't want to step in anything.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What if they put him at shortstop?

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: The hell he does!

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: He does not have the ice water in his veins for big league baseball.

Speaker: furillo
Dialogue: Give me the pen. Higbe grins, hands it over. As Furillo signs...

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Rickey.

Speaker: rickey's voice
Dialogue: Have our friends in the press gone to sleep yet?

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: We are the only people awake on this entire isthmus, Mr. Rickey.

Speaker: rickey's voice
Dialogue: A deliberate violation of the law, needs a little show of force. I leave it to you. Good night, Leo.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Wake up, ladies! Wake the Hell up!  It's come to my attention that some of you fellas don't want to play with Robinson. That you even got a petition drawn up that you're all gonna sign. Well boys, you know what you can do with your petition?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: C'mon, Leo...

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Come on what?!

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Ball players gotta live together, shower together, it's not right to force him on us. Besides, I own a hardware store back home and I --

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Screw your hardware store, Dix! And if you don't like it, screw you! Mr. Rickey'll be happy to make other arrangements for you. Durocher suddenly marches to Higbe, looks like he's going to belt him. As Higbe gulps, Durocher turns to the team.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: I don't care if he's yellow or black or has stripes like a zebra, if Robinson can help us win, and everything I've seen says he can, then he's gonna play on this ball club. Like it, lump it, make your mind up to it because he's coming! And think about this when your heads hit the pillow, he's only the first, boys, only the first. More are coming right behind him. They have talent and they wanna play! He lets that sink a moment.

Speaker: durocher
Dialogue: Yes, sir, they're gonna come diving and scratching. So I'd forget your petition and worry about the field. Because unless you fellas pay a little more attention to your work, they are going to run you right out of the ball park! A petition?  Are you ballplayers or lawyers? As he marches past them and through the doors...

Speaker: sukeforth
Dialogue: Play first base.

Speaker: sukeforth
Dialogue: Well, it's like this. Brooklyn's got a solid second baseman. And they got Pee Wee Reese at short. But first base is up for grabs. Are you catching my drift?

Speaker: sukeforth
Dialogue: Mr. Rickey said he wants you playing conspicuous baseball!

Speaker: sukeforth
Dialogue: Conspicuous.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Bragan, most of your teammates have recanted on this petition nonsense. Are you really here to tell me you don't want to play with Robinson?

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: Yes, Sir. My friends back in Birmingham would never forgive me.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: And your friends here in Brooklyn?  Then I will accommodate you. If you give me your word that you will try your very best for this team until I can work out a trade. That gets Bragan's goat. He jumps up, really mad.

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: Do you think I would quit on anyone?! I don't quit.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Only on yourself apparently. You can go, Bragan.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I received your letter, Dixie.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: I'm keeping my reasons private. Hope you can respect that, sir.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I realize, Dixie, that you have a Southern upbringing, that you would have to subordinate your feelings for the welfare of this venture. I for one would deeply appreciate it. I think we can all learn something.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What I have, Mr. Rickey, is a hardware store back home. It's called Dixie Walker's. Folks don't come because I have the lowest prices, they come because it's called Dixie Walker's. Understand? And I make as much money owning that store as I do playing for you.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Is that what you're you afraid of?  Bragan's a third-stringer, but you bat clean-up. You're popular in Brooklyn. Children look up to you!

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You got my letter; can I go?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I'll start looking for a trade or a sale. But it won't happen until I get value in return. Until then I expect you to drive in runs.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You again. Smith leans back, blinks.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That's right. Me again. Something wrong with that, Jack?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Come on. Jack continues past. As Smith follows...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: They can't keep you on Montreal for long. After these exhibition games, they've got to bring you up.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Do I have to entertain you? More silence, then...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You ever wonder why I sit out in right field with my typewriter on my knees? Does that ever cross your mind? Jack stares out the passenger window, not in the mood. As he looks up at some of the taller buildings they pass...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: It's because Negro reporters aren't allowed in the press box. Jack doesn't answer, doesn't look over. Finally Smith starts talking to himself. Pretending to be Jack.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Why I'm from Detroit, Jack.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: My daddy used to work at Fair Lane. That was Mr. Ford's estate. My daddy was Mr. Henry Ford's cook.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Cooked for him for years, but never once broke bread with him. I'd go to work with daddy sometimes. Play baseball out on the lawn with Mr. Ford's grandchildren. We all had a real good time. But it was understood, if they got tired of playing ball and moved inside to the bowling alley or swimming pool, I was not invited or allowed. The grass was as far as I got. So guess what? You're not the only one with something at stake here.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If I start talking, will you stop?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'd be happy to. Smith stops at a red light.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I apologize. You've been there for me through this more than anyone besides Rae and Mr. Rickey. But I guess that's what bothers me.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I don't like needing someone to be there for me. I don't like needing anyone but myself. I never have.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You are a hard case, Jack Robinson. Is it okay if I keep driving you or should I let you out so you can walk? Jack bursts out laughing. So does Smith.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Branch Rickey cannot afford to upset team chemistry and so the only thing keeping Robinson off the Dodgers now, plainly, is the attitude of the players.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: If it softens at the sight of Jackie's skills, he'll join the club some time between April 10 and April 15. Otherwise, Robinson will spend the year back in Montreal.  For the love of Pete, he batted .625 in the exhibition games against them, us, them -- Against us! Judas Priest! Rickey flummoxed as the phone RINGS from the outer office.

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Maybe you could have Durocher hold a press conference. Demand that he get Robinson on his team.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Durocher. Of course, he's my ace in the hole. Very good, Harold. The phone still rings. Rickey looks to his open door.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Jane Ann! Are you out there? Grumbling, brambly eyebrows twitching, he makes the mistake of answering his own phone.

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: Branch, how are you?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Fine. What can I do for you, Happy?

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: Branch, how would you feel about losing Durocher for a year? Rickey switches the phone from one ear to the other.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Happy, I thought you said lose Durocher for a year.

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: Yes. He was seen in Havana with known gamblers.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Anyone who sets foot in Havana is seen with known gamblers.

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: It's not just one thing, it's an accumulation. I received notice today from the Catholic Youth Organization. Vowing a ban on baseball unless Durocher is punished for his moral looseness.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You're joking.

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: It's this business with the actress in California. She's recently divorced and Durocher is the cause. They may even be illegally married.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Now I'm sure you're joking. Happy checks his nails, returns his hand to the MANICURIST.

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: I wish I were. The CYO buy a lot of tickets, Branch. They draw a lot of water and I can't afford to ruffle their feathers. Am I mixing metaphors there?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You know very well my organization is about to enter a tempest. I need Durocher at the rudder. He's the only man who can handle this much trouble, who loves it in fact. You're chopping off my right hand!

Speaker: happy
Dialogue: I have no choice. I'm going to have to sit your manager, Branch. Leo Durocher is suspended from baseball for a year.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You can't do that! Happy, you son of a bitch! DIAL TONE. Rickey steadies himself, looks to Parrott.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Trouble ahead, Harold. Trouble.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Jane Ann, come in here.  Harold! Parrott sticks his head out from an office down the hall.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Get some employees up here!

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Harold, telegram the press. Say this: The Brooklyn Dodgers today purchased the contract of Jackie Robinson from the Montreal Royals. He will report immediately. As Jack takes it in, he's the only one not smiling.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: jack's voice
Dialogue: Rae, I'm in Brooklyn. Brooklyn... Rachel lets out a triumphant WHOOP!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: What did I tell you?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I love you... As he closes his eyes, absorbs it...

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Opening day nerves. Doing my stomach something awful. Jack nods in commiseration. It's awkward between them. A RUMBLE as a GARBAGE TRUCK goes by.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: There goes another one.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Know when I first heard of you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No I don't.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: On a troop transport, coming back from Guam. A sailor heard it on the radio, told me the Dodgers had signed a Negro player. I said that was fine by me. Then he said the guy was a shortstop. Least you were then. That got me thinking. Thinking gets me scared. Jack smiles, hefts his bottle of Pepto.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Black, white, we're both pink today, huh?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Of garbage trucks? Terrified.

Speaker: hermanski
Dialogue: I'm Hermanski. Welcome to Brooklyn.

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: Hey, man. Ralph Branca. Last, but not least, Spider Jorgensen, his Montreal teammate.

Speaker: jorgensen
Dialogue: We made it, Jack, huh? Good luck. That's it. Everyone else is too busy to come over. As Jack scans for a locker with his name on it, BABE HAMBURGER, the clubhouse manager, steps over.

Speaker: babe
Dialogue: You're looking for your locker, huh, kid? Follow me. They walk over to a hook on the wall. A uniform hangs from it. A FOLDING CHAIR below.

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: You're putting on that uniform, it means you're on my team. But before I play with you I want you to know how I feel about it. I want you to know I don't like it. I want you to know I don't like you. Jack regards him. Stanky doesn't flinch. Maybe he should.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: That's fine. That's how I prefer it. Right out in the open.

Speaker: vendor
Dialogue: C'mon, Brooklyn! Get your Harry M. Stevens special here! As he hands one over, gets his .20 cents in return. Then:

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Okay, okay, that's good. As Jackie's eyes find hers...

Speaker: everett mccooey
Dialogue: O'er the land of the free! And the home of the brave!

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: You're crazy standing that close to him.

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: You got a serious problem, Bragan, you know that?

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: Really? I don't see it.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Opening day, Harold. The world is all future and no past.

Speaker: parrot
Dialogue: A blank page, sir.

Speaker: barber
Dialogue: One out in the bottom of the first. Headed toward the plate for his first big league at bat is Dodger rookie Jackie Robinson. Jackie is very definitely brunette.

Speaker: fan
Dialogue: We're with you, Jackie!

Speaker: barber's voice
Dialogue: Sain looking in. When he's got that fastball working, he can toss a lamb chop past a hungry wolf. The BRAVES CATCHER signals 1'. Here come the pitch. CRACK! It's down the third base line. The THIRD BASEMAN is going to need every ounce of his arm as he fields it at the line, throw across his body to -- FIRST. Where Jack's foot hits the bag an instant before the ball smacks into the first baseman's mitt.

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: You're out! Jack can't believe it. As he trots toward the dugout he looks at the umpire who looks back: I dare you to complain.

Speaker: stands
Dialogue: As the Brooklyn faithful BOO the call, Rachel and Smith watch Jack head decisively toward the dugout. He was safe. Rickey sits down closer to the dugout.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: It's a game of inches, Jackie!

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Get some glasses, ump!

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: Yeah, it's a shame about Leo.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Inevitable I suppose. I asked him if she was worth it and he said yes. How's the retirement?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Is that so?

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: When I took off that Cleveland uniform two years ago, I promised the Mrs. I'd never put on another uniform again. Roses look great and I sleep a whole lot better.

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: Baseball's the only life for an old pepper pot like me, but I promised my wife, Branch.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You promised her you wouldn't put on another uniform. You didn't promise her you wouldn't manage. Wear a suit and tie; Connie Mack still does.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: My car's parked right out front. Harold will show you where. Now what do you say?

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: Men, I don't have much to say. Just, don't be afraid of old Burt Shotton as a manager. You can win the pennant in spite of me. I can not possibly hurt you. The Dodgers trade looks. Not exactly inspirational. As Shotton heads out he pauses by Jack.

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: Are you Robinson?

Speaker: cooke
Dialogue: Mark my words and circle this date. Negroes are going to run the white man straight out of baseball. I'm not prejudiced; it's physiological. They have a longer heel bone. Gives em an unfair speed advantage.

Speaker: another reporter
Dialogue: Was that because his heels are longer, Bob?! As everyone cracks up, everyone but Bob...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm not complaining, I just, I don't know what they want.

Speaker: owner
Dialogue: I'm Lawson Bowman, Jack, the owner of this joint. How's the steak?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm not sure yet. It looks good.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You're lucky you're a boy. DOORWAY - Dressed to go, Rachel holding the baby, looking anxiously out on the street. Suddenly, ALICE the baby-sitter is there. Here she comes up the steps, opens the door.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Sorry I'm late. Class ran long.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's okay. Rachel gently hands the baby over.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's so cold and raw out, I don't want him getting sick at the game.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: He'll be nice and warm here.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm going to be late. She kisses him goodbye, frowns as she heads outside --

Speaker: chapman's voice
Dialogue: Hey! Hey you black Nigger! Jack looks to the visitor's dugout where the Phillies Alabama- born manager BEN CHAPMAN stands at the top of the steps.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Why don't you go back to the cotton fields where you belong!

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Or did you swing your way out of the jungle?! Bring me a banana!

Speaker: barber
Dialogue: Chapman the Phillies manager up on the top step, seems to be chirping something out to Robinson. Chapman a hothead during his playing days with the Yankees.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: What's he saying?

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Bojangles! You sure can dance, snowflake!

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: On first, mouth hanging open. Almost forgets to take a lead. It's an instant Rorschach test.

Speaker: dodger dugout
Dialogue: Shotton and the players look stricken. Even Walker doesn't quite know what to make of it. No one enjoys it, but Higbe.

Speaker: stands
Dialogue: CONCESSION MEN walk closer to listen. The fans range from horrified to some mildly pleased. Rachel looks stricken.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: A fastball inside. He leaps back again. This one was even closer to hitting him. As Jack glares at Dutch...

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Ball two!

Speaker: chapman's voice
Dialogue: Hey, black boy! Hey, shoe shine!

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: You like white girls?! Huh?! Which one of them Dodger boys' wives are you climbing on tonight?! Chapman looks toward...

Speaker: dodger dugout
Dialogue: They don't like that one.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Grips the bat. Watches for the next pitch with bloody mindedness. He hacks at it, lofts a routine fly into left. He's about halfway down to first when the left fielder catches it and Jack can mercifully return to the dugout.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Look at me, baby. Look at me. Finally, Jack glances up to her. She offers her eyes: I'm with you. He looks away. Her witnessing makes it worse.

Speaker: infield
Dialogue: Spider Jorgensen takes a lead off first. At the plate, Stanky lines a single to right. Jorgensen holds at second.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Steps to the batter's box, starts digging in that back foot.

Speaker: visitor's dugout
Dialogue: As Chapman emerges with his two bench players.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Hey, Pee Wee! Dixie! What's this Nigger doing for you all to let him drink from the same water fountain as you?! I hope it's worth it!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Waiting for the pitch. Takes a mighty swing -- CRACKS a towering POP-UP between home plate and the mound. Dutch watches his catcher Seminick settle under it. Waiting.

Speaker: dutch
Dialogue: Hey, is that a home run!?

Speaker: seminick
Dialogue: Yeah! If you're playing in an elevator shaft! Jack veers off the first baseline. Heads for the dugout.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: You don't belong! Look in a mirror! This is a white man's game. Get it through your thick monkey skull! Jack stops short looks at him. Chapman stands his ground.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Stands, watches. Praying this doesn't go south. As Jack finally continues on, Rickey closes his eyes in relief.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Sick for her husband.

Speaker: the dugout
Dialogue: Jack stalks down past the team. No one looks at him. Bragan is ashamed. Dixie tries to look disinterested. Stanky and Reese exchange a helpless glance as Jack continues into:

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: To hell with this. The next white son of a bitch who opens his mouth, I'll smash his goddamn teeth in. Rickey stands there until finally, opening his mouth...

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You can't, Jackie. You know it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm supposed to let this go on?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: These men have to live with

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I have to live with myself, too! And right now I'm living a sermon out there. I'm through with it! Jack is at the end of his rope. All Rickey has are words.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You don't matter right now, Jack. You're in this thing. You don't have the right to pull out from the backing of people who believe in you, respect you and who need you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Is that so?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: If you fight, they won't say Chapman forced you to; they'll just say that you're over your head. That you belong where you are.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Do you know what it's like, having someone do this to you?!

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: No. You do. You're the one living the sermon. In the wilderness. Forty days. All of it. Only you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: And not a damn thing I can do about it.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Of course there is! You can stand up and hit! You can get on base and you can score! You can win this game for us! We need you as well! Everyone needs you.  You're medicine, Jack. Rickey reaches out, touches the wall to stay standing. Jack just breathes as familiar sounds reverb down the tunnel.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: They're taking the field.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Who's playing first? Jack considers him. Everything hangs in the balance. Then:

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I'm gonna need a new bat. As Jack heads back down the tunnel for the field.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Hey, black Nigger! I know you can hear me! If you were a white boy, you know where you'd be right now?! On a bus headed down to Newport News cuz you can't play for shit! Here comes the pitch. Jack nonchalantly sticks his bat out, pokes a soft hit past second. A nothing hit, but he's standing on first. And he looks, well, ferocious in fact. Back on his feet, he spits out a piece of grit he picked up sliding back on his belly. Not bothering to dust himself off, he's turning into something elemental before our eyes.

Speaker: barber
Dialogue: Two strikes now to Reiser as Leonard looks in. Robinson with another big lead off first. He's as restless as a cat with a hot foot.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Steal it, sweetheart. Take it.

Speaker: handley
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I want you to know what goes on here, it don't go for me. Jack barely nods, but he heard.

Speaker: barber's voice
Dialogue: Hermanski steps up.

Speaker: plate
Dialogue: Dutch looking to third, nodding distracted at a sign, looking back to third before... Hermanski cracks a single to left. As Jack crosses the plate, he stares down Chapman on his way to the dugout. As Chapman turns his head, spits --

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: You fellas are making too big a deal out of this. He scored We lost. One to nothing.

Speaker: reporter three
Dialogue: Do you think you were a little hard on Robinson?

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: We treat him the same way we do Hank Greenburg except we call Hank a kike instead of a coon. When we play exhibitions against the Yankees, we call DiMaggio the Wop. They laugh at it. No harm, it's forgotten after the game ends. Chapman tosses away his beer can.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Hey. Let's get the chips off our shoulders and play ball. It's a game, right?

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: I'm going in that Phillie dugout tomorrow and wring Chapman's neck! Rickey considers Parrott, starts laughing. Parrott is hurt.

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Did I say something funny?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: When I first told you about Jackie, you were against it. Now all of a sudden you're worrying about him. How do you suppose that happened?

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Well, any decent minded person --

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Sympathy, Harold, is a Greek word. It means to suffer. I sympathize with you means I suffer with you. This Philadelphia manager has done me a service.

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: A service?!

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Is there an echo in here? Yes, he's creating sympathy on Jackie's behalf. Philadelphia by the way is Greek for brotherly love. The intercom BUZZES.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: What do you want, Bragan?

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: I'd like not to be traded, sir, if it isn't too late.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: What about Robinson? Bragan's been staring at the floor. He looks up now. The low afternoon sun hits his face.

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: I'd like to be his teammate.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: The world's changing; I guess I can live with the change.

Speaker: bragan
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Rickey. Bragan leaves. Rickey looks at Parrott: What do you know?'

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You shouldn't have waited.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: They haven't made a day long enough that I wouldn't wait for you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Give these boys time. It's a three game series. A beat between them, framed by the steel girders around them.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: They are never going to beat you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: They're taking their best shot. I don't want you coming tomorrow. I don't want you to watch that, them beating me.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Wherever you are, I am, too. Look at me. Jack... He looks over. It's not easy for this most proud of men.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I have to watch. So our hearts don't break... Plus I already bought a scorecard. She holds it up. His name the only one filled in.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: And I put your name on it. See? Jack Robinson. He puts his hand out, takes hers.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I did good the day I met you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Baby, you hit a home run.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Hey, porch monkey! Hey Robinson! Hey boy! You know why you're here?

Speaker: eddie stanky
Dialogue: On the bench. Without warning, he blasts off it. MOVE WITH him as he marches toward Chapman who doesn't see him coming.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: You're here to draw those Nigger dollars at the gate for Rickey!

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: Sit down. Sit down or I'll sit you down.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: What's the problem, Stank?

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: You're the problem, you goddamn disgrace! What kind of man are you?! You know he can't fight! Pick on someone who can fight!

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Okay, okay. Jesus. As Chapman disappears into his dugout, Jack whacks a single.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: stanky
Dialogue: For what? You're on my team. What the hell am I supposed to do?

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: Lord, make me an instrument of your peace. Where there is hatred, let me sow love. Where there is injury, let me sow pardon. Where there is darkness, let me sow light. Amens'. We see Rickey sits in the back row, the day heavy on him. A YOUNG GIRL turns, looks at him. Why's a white man here? Rickey smiles, puts a finger to his lips... Shhhh.

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: I speak my mind and they trade me! This ain't the America I know! He glares down to Jack's locker. Jack regards him back. It's Higbe who looks away first. He continues packing.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Where are they sending you, Hig?

Speaker: higbe
Dialogue: Pittsburgh! For cash and some I- talian outfielder named Gionfriddo!

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Do you remember the story, Burt, of the 99 sheep? How one was missing?

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: If you're talking about Dixie, I'd leave the word sheep out of it.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I find myself at odds. I want integration and the pennant. I want to punish Dixie and at the same time I want his salvation.

Speaker: shotton
Dialogue: Can't he just be a good ballplayer? He has to be a good person, too?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: It would be so much simpler if he wasn't batting .385. As Walker finishes, he passes Jack whose turn it is.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Eddie, what's all this talk about your Cardinals refusing to play?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: We're here, aren't we? We didn't come to New York to go to Macy's. Dyer continues past him. Here comes big JOE GARAGIOLA.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Hey, Garagiola --

Speaker: garagiola
Dialogue: Get lost. Here comes STAN MUSIAL, a class act if there ever was one.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Hey, Stan, what's the story?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: National League President Frick says this is America and baseball is America's game. He says one citizen has as much right to play as another.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Why are you doing this, Mr. Rickey?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Because my job is to win. I have an obligation to Brooklyn to put the best team on the field I can. Your presence on the roster increases our chances of winning. Not buying it, Jack looks over at him.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: If this is winning, I'd hate to see us on a losing streak.

Speaker: garagiola
Dialogue: Watch this guy! He can't hit! Especially the curve! He can only get on base bunting! As Jack digs into the box.

Speaker: garagiola
Dialogue: Take your time, Robinson, you're digging your own grave. Big RED MUNGER looks in for the sign. Garagiola flashes a sign: 1'. Wants it inside. Here's the pitch. Inside. Jack just scoots back.

Speaker: barber
Dialogue: Takes a fastball in on the hands. Robinson, who is pitched to a great deal that way, uses a thicker handle bat than most hitters, just because he hits a lot of balls out on his hands.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What's your average, Joe?

Speaker: garagiola
Dialogue: It'd be a lot higher than yours, if I could run as fast as you can.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: No matter how fast you run, you'll never hit as much as you weigh. Garagiola signals for another fastball.

Speaker: garagiola
Dialogue: C'mon, Munger! Boy's got a hole in his bat! Munger throws inside. Jack falls back, strokes a double into the gap.

Speaker: barber's voice
Dialogue: That one wasn't quite in' enough. Robinson punishing the Redbirds with a smart piece of hitting.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Oh Jack...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What is it, Rae?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Nothing. It's just, sometimes when I sit up there with those bastards, those loudmouths in the stands, I know you can hear them.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Don't worry. It's okay.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: No, it's not okay. And I can hear them, too. Jack looks at her, takes her hand in his.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: It worked. I didn't hear a thing. She tries to smiles. As the tears streak her cheeks, he leans in kisses her forehead.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: They're just ignorant.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: If they knew you, they'd be ashamed. She puts her arm around him, draws that strength.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Hold on.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I am holding on.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Long as we hold on, it'll be okay.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: You look lovely, Mrs. Robinson.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I don't know how you do it. Every day, from the 1st to the 9th. Myself? I could pay $100 for a suit and in twenty minutes I'd look like I fell out of bed. Even my shoes look rumpled. They watch Jack crack one high off the Schaefer Beer sign.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I used to think Jack was conceited.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Is that so?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It was the very first thing I noticed about him.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: How did you two meet?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I saw him at a UCLA football game. Even in uniform with a helmet on, his vanity was awful. It was the way he held his hands on his hips. I hated him!

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Trying to catch her in a race. She was the fastest girl in town. Beautiful legs. I finally caught up; we've been together ever since. They sit a moment. Below: Jack nails another one.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I wanted to apologize to you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Everything. I can't apologize to him. He and I both knew what we were getting into. But you. A newlywed, trying to blossom a marriage under all this pressure.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Don't worry about me. Or us. We know who we are. Crack. Jack hits another.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Your husband has humbled me. When this all began I thought I was changing the world and that Jackie was my instrument. Can you imagine? I wish I could help him, but I'm just a spectator.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You help him plenty. Believe me. They watch him rip into another pitch.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Is he able to get things off his chest? So he doesn't burn up?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Yes. I have to let him have that silence at first, let him come to me. But he opens up eventually.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Good. It's too much to carry inside. Does he have any friends on the team?  They're spectators, too. They do admire him though. Rachel looks out to where Reese and Stanky play catch.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Do you think so?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Even the worst of us recognizes courage. Moral courage especially. I have to think they see it. Jackie's a man on trial. He's responding with glory and grace. No one can take their eyes off him.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: He's had himself on trial since the day I met him. No man is harder on himself or gets to himself worse than Jack. But I hope his team- mates know, they're on trial too.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I suppose we all are. You're an astute woman, Mrs. Robinson.

Speaker: pennock
Dialogue: Branch, it's Herb.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: What can I do for you, Herb?

Speaker: pennock
Dialogue: How long have we known each other?

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Twenty years. Maybe more.

Speaker: pennock
Dialogue: Then trust me when I say, Brooklyn's due here tomorrow, but you can not bring that Nigger down here with the rest of your team. Rickey grits his teeth, stays civil.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: And why's that, Herb? His name's Jackie Robinson by the way.

Speaker: pennock
Dialogue: We're just not ready for this sort of thing in Philadelphia.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Herbert, what your team does is your decision. But my team is coming to Philadelphia. With Robinson. If we have to claim the game as a forfeit, we will. That's 9-0 in case you forgot.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Maybe 42's got enough friends in town, we can bunk up.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What's that supposed to mean?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Nothing. It's just, I know when you can't get into a hotel, you got people's houses you can stay at.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What do you want from me, Walker?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: An apology.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Watch your damn hand! And they're lunging at each other. Separated by Reese, Stanky, Branca and Bragan while other players hold off Shotton. Two fights about to break out at the same time.

Speaker: shotten
Dialogue: Grandpa?! I'll show you grandpa! Parrott summons something deep, lets loose a shrill WHISTLE.

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Fellas! Burt! Please! Take the bus to the field! Worry about the game. I'll find another hotel.

Speaker: pennock
Dialogue: There is a great lynch mob among us; they go unhooded and work without rope.  We must remember that all this country's enemies are not beyond the frontiers of our home land.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Some Jew must've wrote that.

Speaker: pennock
Dialogue: This doesn't look good, Ben! It makes the Phillies, look racist! You've got to do something.

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Me?!

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Jackie, excuse me, um, a request came in. The Phillies manager Ben Chapman, he'd like his photo taken with you. Jack pretends to sniff the air around Parrott.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You been drinking, Harold?

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Mr. Rickey thinks it's a good idea. He says it'll be in every sports page in the country. An example that'll show everyone even the most hardened man can change.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Chapman hasn't changed. He's just trying to take the heat off.

Speaker: parrott
Dialogue: Mr. Rickey says it doesn't matter if he's changed. As long as it looks like he's changed. Chapman said he'd come down here. Or meet you in the runway. As Jack slow burns...

Speaker: chapman
Dialogue: Jackie's been accepted in baseball and the Philadelphia organization wish him all the luck we can. I only hope in some small way our trial of fire... helped him along. Jack looks at him: Did he just say that?

Speaker: photographer
Dialogue: How about a picture? Shake hands. Bury the hatchet?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You want a picture? Sure. Jack steps to the on-deck circle, grabs a BASEBALL BAT. Chapman's eyes widen as he starts toward him with it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: We'll hold the bat. That way we don't have to touch skin. Chapman nods, looks relieved. A photographer hands over a bat. Chapman has two hands on the handle. Jack puts one hand on the barrel, the other stays on his hip.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Ben, I hope all your friends back home like the picture. Jack smiles as the flashbulbs go off. Chapman looks dumb.

Speaker: dixie walker
Dialogue: By the dugout with Stanky, watches in disbelief.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Carl, I swear, I never thought I'd see ol' Ben eat shit like that.

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: Ostermeuller, you kraut! You gotta bat, too! Don't you forget!

Speaker: ostermueller
Dialogue: I'm ready, you Wop bastard!

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: What can I do for you, Pee Wee?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Well, Mr. Rickey, it's like this, the series in Cincinnati next week.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: It's an important road trip, we're only three games out of first.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Yes, sir. You know, I'm from Kentucky.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Cincinnati's nearly a home game for you.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I got this letter, sir. I guess some people aren't too happy about me playing with Robinson. Rickey is not liking where this is going; he motions for the letter, scans it, reads the highlights...

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Nigger lover. Watch yourself. We will get you, carpetbagger.  Typical stuff. Reese takes the letter back, a little hurt.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: It's not typical to me.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: How many of these letters have you gotten, Pee Wee?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Just this. Ain't that enough? Rickey looks Reese over a moment. Pushing back his chair he steps over to a filing cabinet.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I'll tell you what they aren't, they aren't letters from the Jackie Robinson fan club. Here -- He thrusts a sheaf of it into Reese's hands. As Reese flips through the stack of hate, reads:

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Get out of baseball, or your baby boy will die.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: Of course he knows. And the FBI. They're taking a threat in Cincinnati pretty seriously. So excuse me if I'm not too shocked at you being called a carpetbagger. You should be proud of it!

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: We'd just like to play ball, Mr. Rickey. That's all we want to do.

Speaker: rickey
Dialogue: I understand. I bet Jackie just wants to play ball. I bet he wishes he wasn't leading the league in hit by pitch. I bet he wishes people didn't want to kill him. But the world isn't so simple anymore. I'm not sure it ever was. We just, baseball ignored it. Now we can't.

Speaker: freckles
Dialogue: Nigger!  We don't want you here!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What's up? Now cries of CARPETBAGGER! cut through. PEE WEE, HOW CAN YOU PLAY WITH THIS BLACK BASTARD!? Reese stares up at the worst hecklers along the first base line. He looks a little sad.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: They can say what they want; we're here to play baseball.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Just a bunch of crackpots still fighting the Civil War.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Hell, we'd a won that son of a gun if the cornstalks had held out. We just ran out of ammunition. Jack laughs. Reese has a funny way of saying it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Better luck next time, Pee Wee. Reese impulsively puts his arm around Jack's shoulder, stares into the Cincy dugout.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Ain't gonna be a next time. All we got is right now. This right here. Know what I mean? Walker reacting out in right. The crowd shuts down, some in shock at the gesture. Jack surprised also.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What're you thanking me for?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I've got family here from Louisville. Up there somewhere. I need em to know who I am.

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Hey! Number one! You playing ball or socializing?

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: Playing ball, ump! Playing ball!

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: You ever write about white guys in your paper? I mean, if I threw a no hitter and Jackie got a base hit, what would the headline be?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Jackie leads Dodgers to victory. Again. Under that: white Italian guy does ok. They all laugh.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: I'd call your folks for ya, Ralph. Tell em how you did.

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: No problem. It'll still make the Post. They play their hands as they talk.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: We are on some kind of winning streak, huh boys? And I don't mean cards.

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: Hey, maybe forty of our last fifty.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Thirty-two and fifteen actually. Since the 4th of July.

Speaker: branca
Dialogue: Math is why I throw a baseball for a living.

Speaker: reese
Dialogue: This next series against the Cardinals, it's a big one. They look over at Jack who hasn't said a word. It's his play. He lays his cards down. Deadpan as he wins the hand.

Speaker: jack
